title: Stranger Things and It star Finn Wolfhard turns up the creep factor in The Turning trailer
text:
He's no stranger to delivering scares, having starred in It and Stranger Things.

And Finn Wolfhard is once again turning up the creep factor, in a skin-crawling trailer for his latest horror film, The Turning.

The 16-year-old actor stars as Miles, an orphaned boy with a secret, who is placed in the care of new governess Kate (played by Blade Runner 2049's Mackenzie Davis).

Chilling: Finn Wolfhard is once again turning up the creep factor, in a skin-crawling trailer for his latest film, The Turning

The trailer begins with Kate approaching a creepy mansion and is asked by Mrs. Grose (Barbara Martin) if she's ever worked as a nanny before.

'This is my first live-in job,' replies Kate.

'Well I hope you know what you're doing,' Mrs. Grose tells her, ominously.

'The children are very special, Kate. They're thoroughbreds'.

IT factor: The 16-year-old actor stars as Miles, an orphaned boy with a secret, who is placed in the care of new governess Kate (played by Blade Runner 2049's Mackenzie Davis)

Mackenzie Davis: The trailer begins with Kate approaching a creepy mansion and is asked by Mrs. Grose (Barbara Martin) if she's ever worked as a nanny before

The trailer then introduces the children, played by Wolfhard and Brooklynn Prince -who seem troubled and troublesome in equal parts.

In voiceover, we hear Kate ask 'May I ask how the parents died?' to which Mrs. Grose replies 'It's not that simple'.

In a particularly disturbing scene, Kate and the children come across a fish dying out of water - only for Miles to stomp it to death.

When Kate chastises him, he replies calmly that 'Nothing should have to suffer'.

Orphans: The trailer then introduces the children, played by Wolfhard and Brooklynn Prince [pictured, R] -who seem troubled and troublesome in equal parts

Harsh: In a particularly disturbing scene, Kate and the children come across a fish dying out of water - only for Miles to stomp it to death

Later in the trailer, Kate explores a dark, neglected room inside the mansion, only to be startled by a white, ghostly figure.

From there, the creepy imagery ramps up, with quick cuts giving glimpses of disembodies hands crawling over Kate and a huge spider crawling into Miles' mouth as he lies unconscious, with apparent bruising around his neck.

During the terrifying sequence, Miles tells Kate that 'keeping the lights on won't keep you safe,' while Kate later exclaims 'I don't want to play any more!'

Revamp: The film is a modern adaptation of the 1898 horror novella the Turn of the Screw by Henry James

Plot: Distributor Universal Pictures gave the following synopsis for the film: 'At a mysterious estate in the Maine countryside, newly appointed nanny Kate is charged with the care of two disturbed orphans, Flora and Miles. She quickly discovers that both the children and the house are harboring dark secrets and things may not be as they appear'

The film is a modern adaptation of the 1898 horror novella the Turn of the Screw by Henry James.

Distributor Universal Pictures gave the following synopsis for the film: 'At a mysterious estate in the Maine countryside, newly appointed nanny Kate is charged with the care of two disturbed orphans, Flora and Miles. She quickly discovers that both the children and the house are harboring dark secrets and things may not be as they appear.'

The Turning is scheduled to be released on January 24, 2020.
